thread.title: Blue Jays-Royals ALCS Game 4 tip sheet
thread.title_full: Blue Jays-Royals ALCS Game 4 tip sheet | Toronto Star

author: Brendan Kennedy
title: Blue Jays-Royals ALCS Game 4 tip sheet
text:
Game 3 was a happy homecoming for the Blue Jays, who broke out for 11 runs, including three homers, inside the hitter-friendly familiarity of the Rogers Centre. They will be looking to even the series in Game 4 as 40-year-old knuckleballer R.A. Dickey goes up against 6-foot-10 Royals’ right-hander Chris Young. Here’s what you need to know about today’s game.
Toronto Blue Jays vs. Kansas City Royals
ALCS Game 4
Rogers Centre
First pitch : 4:07 p.m. EST
Roof status: Not officially announced yet, but with a 40-per-cent chance of rain at game time, expect it to be closed as it has been throughout the post-season.
Starting pitchers: RH R.A. Dickey (11-11, 3.91) vs. RH Chris Young (11-6, 3.06)
TV: Fox Sports-1, simulcast in Canada on Sportsnet.
Projected lineups:
Blue Jays:
Ben Revere – LF
Josh Donaldson – 3B
Jose Bautista – RF
Edwin Encarnacion – DH
Chris Colabello – 1B
Troy Tulowitzki – SS
Russell Martin – C
Kevin Pillar – CF
Ryan Goins – 2B
Royals:
Alcides Escobar – SS
Ben Zobrist – 2B
Lorenzo Cain – CF
Eric Hosmer – 1B
Kendrys Morales – DH
Mike Moustakas – 3B
Sal Perez – C
Alex Gordon – LF
Alex Rios – RF
Young’s the man
John Rieger
Chris Young, an extreme fly-ball pitcher, is slated to start Game 4 for the Royals. He went 11-6 with a 3.06 ERA during the regular season.
Royals’ manager Ned Yost said he had no reservations about going with Chris Young, an extreme fly-ball pitcher, to start Game 4, citing his career numbers against the Jays (he has held Josh Donaldson, Jose Bautista, Edwin Encarnacion and Troy Tulowitzki to just seven combined hits in 47 career at-bats). But Young, who had the highest fly-ball rate of any starting pitcher this season, has never pitched at the Rogers Centre, which is traditionally an inhospitable place for fly-ball pitchers.
Bullpen rested
Charlie Riedel
Kansas City Royals relief pitcher Kelvin Herrera warms up in the bullpen during Game 2 of the ALDS against the Astros. The Royals’ bullpen was the best in the American League this year.
One bright side for the Royals in Game 3 is how they did not have to use any of their marquee bullpen arms — Wade Davis, Ryan Madson, Kelvin Herrera or Luke Hochevar — in the loss. That means the fearsome quartet will be well-rested and available to pitch in both Game 4 and Game 5. “Now we’ve got two more games here, we can go ahead and pour the coals on them,” Yost said. The Royals’ bullpen was the best in the American League this year.
Hot wings
Rick Madonik
Despite a lingering finger injury, Edwin Encarnacion is tied for the team lead with 10 post-season hits.
Despite dealing with a sprained middle finger on his left hand, Jays’ designated hitter Edwin Encarnacion has looked no worse for wear of late. He’s tied for the team lead with 10 post-season hits and he has multiple hits in four of the last five games, racking up six singles, a double and a homer in that span.
Players to watch:
Russell Martin
The Jays’ catcher has faced Chris Young more than any of his teammates and he has fared well against him in his career, going 9-for-30 with a pair of doubles and six walks.
Alcides Escobar
The Royals’ speedy lead-off hitter, who already has seven hits this series, is 6-for-18 vs. Dickey in his career.
